wordpressPost.title: At Home Thyroid Test
wordpressPost.content:
It’s believed by many doctors that our basal metabolic temperature or BMT is the most accurate measure of thyroid function.

We can check our own BMT at home by using an oral thermometer.  Not a digital one however.

This is how you do it:

  1. When you are ready to go to bed, shake an oral thermometer down and put it next to your bed where you can easily reach it in the morning. Don’t shake it down in the morning because this can raise your body temperature and the test won’t be accurate.
  2. When you wake up in the morning, put the thermometer in your armpit and leave it there for 10 minutes. Try and lie as still as you can.  Don’t get up or move as this too will increase your metabolic rate thus, raising your temperature.
  3. After the 10 minutes are up, record your temperature.
  4. Repeat this process for 3 – 5 days (at least 3 but preferably 5).

If your BMT consistently falls below 97.8 F, you may have an underactive thyroid.  BMT Normally ranges from 97.8 F to 98.2 F.

**If you have any kind of infection wait to take the test.

If you fall below and you have some of the symptoms below, it may be time to see your doctor for a blood test.

Symptoms of Hypothyroidism

Fatigue

Weakness

Weight gain or increased difficulty losing weight

Coarse, dry hair

Dry, rough pale skin

Hair loss

Cold intolerance (you can’t tolerate cold temperatures like those around you)

 

MYAGINGANDWELLNESS.COM

Muscle cramps and frequent muscle aches

Constipation

Depression

Irritability

Memory loss

Abnormal menstrual cycles

Decreased libido

“Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the body lacks sufficient thyroid hormone. Since the main purpose of thyroid hormone is to “run the body’s metabolism,” it is understandable that people with this condition will have symptoms associated with a slow metabolism. The estimates vary, but approximately 10 million Americans have this common medical condition. In fact, as many as 10% of women may have some degree of thyroid hormone deficiency.   Hypothyroidism is more common than you would believe, and millions of people are currently hypothyroid and don’t know it.”
